children.value: PCA finds the low dimensional structure of high dimensional data.
Whereas k-means clustering sought to partition the data into homogeneous subgroups, principal component analysis (PCA) will seek to find, if it exists, low-dimensional structure in the data set

children.html: {x}i=1n \{ x\}_{i = 1}^{n} {x}i=1n​
xi∈Rdx_{i} \in \mathbb{R}^{d} xi​∈Rd

children.value: The features in which the data vary the most describes this lower-dimensional subspace.
PCA finds a low-dimensional representation of the data that captures most of the interesting behavior.
Here, “interesting” will be defined as variability. This is analogous to computing “composite” features (i.e. linear combinations of entries in each

children.html: xi x_{i} xi​

children.value: that explain most of the variability in the data.)
Take a simple example: if there exists one unit vector

children.value: Typically in unsupervised learning, we are interested in understanding relationships between data points and not necessarily bulk properties of the data. If the data has a sufficiently large mean, i.e.

children.html: μ=1n∑ixi \mu = \frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i}x_{i} μ=n1​i∑​xi​

children.value: is sufficiently far from zero, the best approximation of each data point is roughly

children.html: μ\muμ

children.alt: Figure 10: For data with a non-zero mean the best approximation isachieved using a vector similar to the mean; in contrast, most of theinteresting behavior in the data may occur in completely differentdirections.

children.value: Therefore, to actually understand the relationship between features we would like to center our data before applying PCA by deleting the mean from data. Specifically, we let

children.html: x^i=xi−μ{\hat{x}}_{i} = x_{i} - \mux^i​=xi​−μ
μ=1n∑ixi. \mu = \frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i}x_{i}. μ=n1​i∑​xi​.

children.value: We now simply work with the centered feature vectors

children.html: {x^i}i=1n \{{\hat{x}}_{i}\}_{i = 1}^{n} {x^i​}i=1n​

children.value: and will do so throughout the remainder of these notes.

To do PCA, we want to find a small set of composite features that capture most of the variability in the data. To illustrate this point, we will first consider finding a single composite feature that captures the most variability in the data set, then proceed to find the 2nd one, 3rd one...
Mathematically, we want to find a vector

children.value: such that the sample variance of the scalars

children.html: zi=ϕTx^iz_{i} = \phi^{T}{\hat{x}}_{i}zi​=ϕTx^i​

children.value: is as large as possible. Note

children.value: We want to pick a relatively small

children.html: kkk

children.value: such that a relatively big ratio can be achieved. In practice, we can do a similar thing as we did with K-Means: we can pick

children.html: k k k

children.value: by identifying when we have diminishing returns in explaining variance by adding more principal components, i.e. looking for a knee in the plot of singular values.

A common use of PCA is for data visualization. In particular, if we have high dimensional data that is hard to visualize we can sometimes see key features of the data by plotting its projection onto a few (1, 2, or 3) principal components. For example, if

children.html: d=2 d = 2 d=2

children.value: this corresponds to forming a scatter plot of

children.html: (ϕ1Tx^i,ϕ2Tx^i) (\phi_{1}^{T}{\hat{x}}_{i},\phi_{2}^{T}{\hat{x}}_{i})(ϕ1T​x^i​,ϕ2T​x^i​)
